author: Bageshree S
text:
It is unfortunate that educated people are falling prey to superstitions, says Karnataka Chief Minister Siddaramaiah

Amid heated debate on “intolerance”, Karnataka Chief Minister Siddaramaiah has said that there was an attempt by “vested interests” to stifle voices of those speaking up on the issue.

In his televised address through the Doordarshan on Republic Day on Tuesday, he said a range of people working to build the nation on democratic principles — public intellectuals as well as ordinary citizens — were concerned over growing intolerance.

While intolerance has existed from time immemorial, those who suffered it for centuries are now questioning it. “Some vested interests are portraying the act of questioning itself as crime,” said the Chief Minister. This, he said, was “dangerous” and people need to wake up to it.

“Some people are talking today of building the nation on the foundation of religious nationalism… This is contrary to the spirit of plural democracy,” he said and added that progress depends on rational thought and development of science and technology. It was unfortunate that the educated are falling prey to superstitions, he said.

title: Why is it a crime to speak up against intolerance: Siddaramaiah
